basics.name: Henry Hansen
basics.label: Fisheries Ecologist
basics.summary: Henry is an applied ecologist focusing on freshwater and marine natural resource managment problems.

work.summary: Investigate habitat alterations of rivers and fish community responses. Develop novel quantitative methods to better understand river dynamics. Produce relevant tools and approaches for river ecosystem managers and practitioners.
highlights: Training and funding provided by European Union Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Programme under the Marie Sklodowska-Curie Actions.
Hosted by Karlstad University's River Ecology and Management Team, RivEM.

work.company: Leibniz Institute of Freshwater Ecology and Inland Fisheries
work.summary: Implement acoustic reciever array in the southern Baltic Sea. Manage and lead field, lab, and biological database operations and budgets. Oversee training of master students and support staff.
Implement fish tagging efforts and acoustic reciever array deployment in Lake Winnipeg and Red River of the North.
Manage GIS databases, operations, and analyses for the county and city of Livingston.

work.company: Montana Association of Geographic Information Professionals
work.summary: Coordinate and improve operations of the association and expand membership.
Design and publish Park County Atlas on ArcGIS Online
Assist research scientists in fish and amphibian movement ecology studies.
Assist mussel biologists in statewide monitoring, surveys, and laboratory experiments.
Assist park rangers with trail clearing. Support Yellowstone Fisheries lake trout removal program.
Manage and train undergraduate volunteers for population genetics sequencing lab.
Assist undergraduate GIS students with GIS labs.
Oversee training of undergraduate students for quantitative chemistry course.

awards.title: Best Student Presentation Award
awards.awarder: Minnesota and Dakota Chapter American Fisheries Society
awards.summary: Awarded to the best student presentation at the annual chapter meeting

awards.title: Joan Duffy Award
awards.awarder: North Central Division American Fisheries Society
awards.summary: Awarded to an exceptional student presenting at the Midwest Fish & Wildlife Conference

awards.title: Special Achievement in GIS Award
awards.summary: Awarded to organizations that set new precedents throughout the GIS community

awards.title: Samuel E. Wood Award
awards.summary: Highest and most prestigious non-academic award possible for any UW- Stout student, awarded for leadership and contributions to the university, and student body.

publications.name: An Unseen Synchrony or Recurrent Resource Pulse Opportunity? Linking Fisheries with Aeroecology
publications.publisher: Remote Sensing in Ecology and Conservation
publications.summary: Hatch dynamics revealed nocturnal emergence behaviour with annual variations in intensity, spatial extent, and origin. We found that the hatch was likely a pulse resource feeding opportunity for channel catfish, common carp, freshwater drum, and walleye instead of a synchronized feeding event.

publications.name: Retention of T-Bar Anchor Tags for Channel Catfish in the Red River of the North
publications.publisher: North American Journal of Fisheries Management
publications.summary: When instantaneous estimates of tag retention are obtained, T-bar anchor tags may be appropriate for studies that evaluate population parameters for Channel Catfish over extended periods.

publications.name: Exit Here: Strateges for Dealing with Aging Dams and Reservoirs
publications.summary: No comprehensive strategy exists to inform both the range of actions that can be applied to such infrastructure and how such actions would influence biophysical, socioeconomic, and geopolitical tradeoffs. The development of proactive exit strategies is a critical first step in ensuring controlled transitions for aging dams and reservoirs.

publications.name: Analysing Habitat Connectivity and Home Ranges of Bigmouth Buffalo and Channel Catfish Using a Large-Scale Acoustic Receiver Network
publications.summary: The study demonstrated large home ranges in the Lake Winnipeg basin and evidence of frequent transborder movements between Canada and the United States. The study also highlighted successful downstream fish passage at some barriers, whereas some barriers limited or completely blocked upstream movement.
